news_summary: India's Durga Puja celebrations are inspiring social change by blending traditional worship with community empowerment.
news_summary_fr: Les célébrations de Durga Puja en Inde inspirent le changement social en associant le culte traditionnel à l'autonomisation des communautés.
news_summary_es: Las celebraciones indias de Durga Puja inspiran el cambio social al combinar el culto tradicional con la capacitación de la comunidad.

articles.title: India’s Durga Puja, where worship meets social change
articles.summary: India’s eastern state of Bengal transformed this week into the world’s largest public art festival - an immersive blend of worship, artistic expression, and social messaging, thanks to an annual Hindu festival known as Durga Puja.
articles.content:
Inscribed by the UN cultural agency, UNESCO, in 2021 as an element of Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity, Durga Puja isn’t just a festival, it’s a city-wide act of reimagination, one that resonates with the Bengali diaspora and others around the world.

For a few autumn nights, the city of Kolkata (and other parts of West Bengal) became an open-air gallery where local communities build dazzling temporary temples or pandals, artisans from Kumartoli sculpt the goddess from river clay, drummers (dhaakis) roll thunder through the streets, and millions wander from one illuminated dreamscape to the next.

The festivities drew to a close on Thursday.

© UN News/Rohit Upadhyay Festival goers visit a Durga Puja pandal in Kolkata.

What looks like a spectacle is actually a community in motion: local clubs raising funds, families volunteering, craftspeople collaborating, and entire local economies springing to life around food, lights, music, and art.

Families map their “pandal-hopping” routes, musicians set the rhythm, food stalls weave the city together, and the city itself becomes a stage. All kinds of divisions – class, caste, ethnicity – in this city of teeming millions, melt away.

UNESCO recognition

UNESCO recognised the Durga Puja, named after the Hindu goddess Durga, in 2021 describing it as “the best instance of the public performance of religion and art, and a thriving ground for collaborative artists and designers.”

As Tim Curtis, UNESCO Representative in India, explained, “It embodies the Sarbojonin spirit - ‘for all people’ - that has defined community worship since 1926. From clay sculptors to drummers, designers to local organizers, the entire city contributes to one of the most vibrant cultural expressions in the world.”

This is heritage not locked away in monuments but alive in practice, passed hand-to-hand through craftsmanship, reimagined every year with new themes, and binding communities across class, faith, and language.

Durga Puja is also a creative economy powerhouse. A 2019 study estimated the festival’s industries generate $4.53 billion, 2.58 per cent of West Bengal’s GDP.

Art with a message

For Shombi Sharp, United Nations Resident Coordinator in India, this year marked his first visit to the century-old pandal now spotlighting sustainable agriculture, highlighting the broader importance of the Sustainable Development Goals.

© UN News/Rohit upadyay UN Resident Coordinator in India, Shombi Sharp visits a Durga Puja pandal in Kolkata, India.

He told UN News, “Normally you see Goddess Durga defeating evil – here the ‘evil’ is pesticides and unsustainable farming practices. Behind me stands a display with 280 rice varieties from eastern and northeastern India. That’s 12-13 million visitors being exposed to powerful messages about organic agriculture, biodiversity, and sustainability.”

Another headline-grabber is an AI-themed pandal that fuses devotion with digital imagination. Goddess Durga appears in her traditional form - ten arms and a lion – while the backdrop bursts with circuit-board patterns, glowing data streams, and neon light.

The point is clear: faith and technology can co-exist; even in a futuristic frame.

Visitor reactions mirror this blend of wonder and caution. One 30-year-old lab technician from Kolkata, Nupur Hajara said “the more positively people receive AI, the better. If they take it negatively, that won’t help – right?”

© UN News/Rohit Upadhyay Figurines made with electronic waste material are displayed in a pandal or temple.

IT professional, Sumitam Shom explained: “Durga Puja is our biggest, most special festival - and now AI is part of the conversation. It can do a lot of good, but there are risks too, especially fraud. Deepfakes and viral images are real concerns. Without safeguards, someone could misuse photos and deceive people. So, it’s crucial that we use these technologies responsibly.”

Adding a different register of urgency, another pandal with the theme of “Shabdo” (“Sound”) draws attention for its poignant focus on the vanishing sounds of nature – chirping birds, rustling leaves, croaking frogs – captured through immersive, sensory design.

A meditation on nostalgia

It was a meditation on environmental loss and nostalgia, asking what it means for the sounds of nature within a city to grow quieter as habitats shrink.

Raja, a pandal visitor, put it simply: “You barely see birds anymore. My grandfather used to tell me how common they were; now they’re rare - partly, we believe, due to mobile network impacts. This pandal is our way to wake up the community, to learn how to bring the birds back and to start working on it together.”

Many other pandals also echo urgent social themes. One honours acid attack survivors, not only raising awareness but celebrating their dignity and contributions. Another highlights water conservation.

© UN News/Rohit Upadhyay A Puja pandal explores the theme of the vanishing sounds of birds in urban areas.

For young visitors too, the messages resonate. Tisa, an 18-year-old student at a pandal dedicated to water conservation, reflected that “groundwater is depleting day by day. This is the best way to spread awareness to the public.”

Making Puja accessible to all

Durga Puja is also taking a step toward inclusivity.

In June 2025, UNESCO and the UN in India, working with organizations of persons with disabilities, launched comprehensive accessibility guidelines for festival organisers.

The results are visible on the ground. Ramps and barrier-free layouts ease mobility, Braille signage and sign-language interpreters expand communication, and quiet seating areas provide allow people to rest.

As the UN’s Shombi Sharp recalled, “We heard from a father who, for the first time in 17 years, was able to bring his daughter, a wheelchair user, to celebrate Durga Puja. That was an incredibly emotional moment.”

articles.personality_title: Durga Puja in Bengal blends art, community, and social messages
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Durga Puja is a yearly Hindu festival celebrated mainly in West Bengal, India. It honors the goddess Durga and has been recognized by UNESCO as an important cultural event. The festival is known for its artistic displays, music, and community involvement.

**What happened** – This year, the festival turned Kolkata and nearby areas into a huge open-air art gallery. People built temporary temples called pandals, created clay sculptures of the goddess, and enjoyed music and food together. Many pandals focused on important topics like sustainable farming, artificial intelligence, nature conservation, and supporting acid attack survivors. The festival ended recently after drawing millions of visitors.

**Impact** – Durga Puja is more than a religious event; it brings people together across different backgrounds. It supports local artists, craftsmen, and businesses, contributing billions to the region’s economy. The festival also spreads important social messages, like protecting the environment and using technology responsibly. New accessibility features help people with disabilities join the celebrations, making the event more inclusive.

**What's next step** – Organizers will continue to improve accessibility and include new themes each year to raise awareness on social issues. The festival’s success in combining tradition with modern ideas suggests it will keep inspiring communities and supporting local economies in the future.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Durga Puja in Bengal is a vibrant festival that mixes art, faith, and social change while uniting communities and supporting local livelihoods.
articles.personality_title_fr: Durga Puja au Bengale allie art, communauté et messages sociaux
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Durga Puja est une fête hindoue annuelle célébrée principalement au Bengale occidental, en Inde. Elle honore la déesse Durga et a été reconnue par l’UNESCO comme un événement culturel important. Le festival est connu pour ses œuvres artistiques, sa musique et l’implication de la communauté.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Cette année, la fête a transformé Kolkata et ses environs en une immense galerie d’art en plein air. Les habitants ont construit des temples temporaires appelés pandals, créé des sculptures en argile de la déesse, et apprécié la musique et la nourriture ensemble. Plusieurs pandals ont mis en avant des sujets importants comme l’agriculture durable, l’intelligence artificielle, la conservation de la nature et le soutien aux survivants d’attaques à l’acide. Le festival s’est terminé récemment après avoir attiré des millions de visiteurs.

**Impact** – Durga Puja est plus qu’un événement religieux ; il rassemble des personnes de divers horizons. Il soutient les artistes locaux, les artisans et les commerces, apportant des milliards à l’économie régionale. Le festival diffuse aussi des messages sociaux importants, comme la protection de l’environnement et l’utilisation responsable de la technologie. De nouvelles mesures d’accessibilité permettent aux personnes en situation de handicap de participer, rendant l’événement plus inclusif.

**Prochaine étape** – Les organisateurs continueront d’améliorer l’accessibilité et d’intégrer chaque année de nouveaux thèmes pour sensibiliser aux questions sociales. Le succès du festival à combiner tradition et idées modernes laisse penser qu’il continuera d’inspirer les communautés et de soutenir les économies locales.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Durga Puja au Bengale est un festival vivant qui mêle art, foi et changement social tout en unissant les communautés et en soutenant les moyens de subsistance locaux.
articles.personality_title_es: Durga Puja en Bengala une arte, comunidad y mensajes sociales
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Durga Puja es un festival hindú anual que se celebra principalmente en Bengala Occidental, India. Honra a la diosa Durga y ha sido reconocido por la UNESCO como un evento cultural importante. El festival es conocido por sus expresiones artísticas, música y participación comunitaria.

**Qué pasó** – Este año, el festival transformó Kolkata y sus alrededores en una gran galería de arte al aire libre. La gente construyó templos temporales llamados pandals, creó esculturas de arcilla de la diosa y disfrutó juntos de música y comida. Muchos pandals se centraron en temas importantes como la agricultura sostenible, la inteligencia artificial, la conservación de la naturaleza y el apoyo a sobrevivientes de ataques con ácido. El festival terminó recientemente tras recibir millones de visitantes.

**Impacto** – Durga Puja es más que un evento religioso; une a personas de diferentes orígenes. Apoya a artistas locales, artesanos y negocios, aportando miles de millones a la economía regional. El festival también difunde mensajes sociales importantes, como proteger el medio ambiente y usar la tecnología con responsabilidad. Nuevas características de accesibilidad ayudan a personas con discapacidad a participar, haciendo el evento más inclusivo.

**Próximo paso** – Los organizadores seguirán mejorando la accesibilidad e incluyendo nuevos temas cada año para crear conciencia sobre temas sociales. El éxito del festival al combinar tradición con ideas modernas sugiere que continuará inspirando a las comunidades y apoyando las economías locales.

**Resumen en una frase** – Durga Puja en Bengala es un festival vibrante que combina arte, fe y cambio social mientras une a las comunidades y apoya los medios de vida locales.
articles.image_prompt: A vibrant, detailed painting of a glowing clay goddess Durga with ten arms riding a majestic lion, surrounded by intricately crafted temporary temple structures (pandals) adorned with warm lantern lights and traditional drums, interwoven with symbolic circuit-board patterns and flowing rice grains representing sustainable agriculture, all set within a bustling, inclusive community scene with ramps and Braille motifs subtly integrated into the architecture, rendered in natural earthy tones and soft warm colors.
